introParagraph.content: I’m a product designer living and working in San Francisco, spending my days thinking through designs, untangling complex problems and wriggling around in the details.

columns.title: Research & Discovery
columns.content: Understanding user needs, behaviors, business goals, and technical constraints is important in forming a solid foundation from which informed design decisions can be made. Focusing on this, as well as building a shared understanding of the product experience across stakeholders, is key in the early stages of any design.

columns.title: Design & Prototype
columns.content: With the information gleaned in the discovery phase, the Design phase can begin…and it usually begins with sketches. Lots of sketches. Once an idea begins to take shape, fidelity and details are steadily increased and the focus is shifted from sketches to wireframes, user stories, and architecture maps. Prototypes are also used to test ideas with users and generate buy-in from stakeholders on the team.

columns.title: Test & Iterate
columns.content: Testing is leveraged early and often to understand how a design is resonating with users. Learnings are then used to inform iterations and optimize design solutions. From here, Engineering is brought in to first understand the intended behavior, and then to implement. After launch, user behavior and feedback is gathered, with necessary adjustments made as needed.

contact.content: Want to know more? Get in touch.
